title: 108_hr4116
content: The Act may be cited as the "American Bald Eagle Recovery and National Emblem Commemorative Coin Act". The bald eagle, designated as the national emblem of the United States in 1782, symbolizes freedom, democracy, and American values. It is unique to North America and is prominently featured in the Great Seal of the United States and various government seals. The bald eagle, a symbol of American beliefs and traditions, has influenced art, music, history, literature, commerce, and culture since the founding of the nation. Once endangered, it has made a gradual recovery and was upgraded from "endangered" to "threatened" status under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The bald eagle, symbolizing American beliefs and traditions, has influenced various aspects of society. It was upgraded from "endangered" to "threatened" status under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The administration is likely to delist the bald eagle by 2008. Recovery efforts were successful due to the collaboration of agencies, organizations, and citizens. Continued care and habitat protection are crucial for the bald eagle's survival. Monitoring of bald eagle nests in 49 states is required for 5 years post-delisting. Due to budget cuts, funding for bald eagle care and monitoring programs has decreased annually. Congress aims to mark the bald eagle's removal from the "threatened" species list in 2008 and encourages public participation in conservation efforts. Opportunity for voluntary participation in raising funds for bald eagle recovery and preservation efforts through a special American Eagle Fund endowment managed by the American Eagle Foundation. Congress should authorize coins celebrating the bald eagle's recovery, removal from endangered species list, and the 35th anniversary of the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The bald eagle was designated as an "endangered" species under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The bald eagle was designated as an "endangered" species under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins to celebrate the recovery of the bald eagle, America's national symbol of freedom, and the 35th anniversary of the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The text chunk discusses the specifications for half dollar clad coins, which contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. The coins must weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and be minted to specific standards outlined in the law. Additionally, the coins minted under this Act are considered legal tender and numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the bald eagle and its significance, with inscriptions including the coin's value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single U.S. Mint facility during a one-year period starting on January 1, 2008. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act will include surcharges: $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $3 per half dollar coin. Surcharges received will be promptly paid to the American Eagle Foundation of Tennessee to support its works. The Foundation will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge may exceed the specified amounts. The Act mandates surcharges for all coins minted, with specific amounts per coin denomination. However, no surcharge can be imposed if it would exceed the annual limit of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year. The Secretary of the Treasury has the authority to provide guidance on this limitation.
